title: Blaxhall
text:
Blaxhall is a village and <a href="civil%20parish">civil parish</a> in the <a href="East%20Suffolk%20%28district%29">East Suffolk</a> district of the <a href="English%20county">English county</a> of <a href="Suffolk">Suffolk</a>. Located around south-west of <a href="Leiston">Leiston</a> and <a href="Aldeburgh">Aldeburgh</a>, in 2007 its population was estimated to be 220, measured at 194 in the 2011 Census.
The parish council owns <a href="Blaxhall%20Common">Blaxhall Common</a>, a <a href="Site%20of%20Special%20Scientific%20Interest">Site of Special Scientific Interest</a> located on the <a href="Suffolk%20Coast%20and%20Heaths">Suffolk Coast and Heaths</a> <a href="Area%20of%20Outstanding%20Natural%20Beauty">Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty</a> to the south-east of the village. The area is one of the few remaining areas of lowland dry <a href="heathland">heathland</a> in the Suffolk Sandlings and is managed by <a href="Suffolk%20Wildlife%20Trust">Suffolk Wildlife Trust</a> as a nature reserve.
The Blaxhall Stone is a large stone located at Stone Farm which, according to local legend, has been constantly increasing in size since it was dug up in the 19th century.
Blaxhall is the subject of the historian George Ewart Evans' book Ask the Fellows who Cut the Hay. It focuses on 19th century rural life it the village.
